passage:
(1) Susan Brownell Anthony, born in 1820 to a Quaker family in Massachusetts, would emerge as one of the most influential figures in the American women's suffrage movement despite facing ridicule, threats, and even arrest for her convictions. While contemporary discourse often portrays Anthony as solely focused on voting rights, her activism encompassed a broader spectrum of interconnected social reforms including temperance, labor rights, and abolition. What distinguished Anthony from many of her contemporaries was her unflinching pragmatism; she recognized that without political enfranchisement, women would remain powerless to effect meaningful change across all spheres of public life. This strategic insight led her to prioritize suffrage as the cornerstone upon which other rights could subsequently be built.

(2) Anthony's partnership with Elizabeth Cady Stanton proved extraordinarily productive, combining Anthony's organizational prowess and tireless speaking engagements with Stanton's intellectual and rhetorical gifts. Together, they founded the National Woman Suffrage Association in 1869, published the influential newspaper 'The Revolution,' and co-authored the first three volumes of the monumental 'History of Woman Suffrage.' Their collaboration exemplified effective feminist coalition-building, though it was not without conflict, particularly regarding tactical differences and competing priorities. Anthony's willingness to align temporarily with controversial allies and to postpone other social justice objectives for the sake of winning the vote occasionally generated friction even among dedicated suffragists, illustrating the strategic complexities inherent in any sweeping social movement.

(3) Perhaps most significantly, Anthony reconceptualized American citizenship in radically inclusive terms through her activism. Her famous act of civil disobedience—voting illegally in the 1872 presidential election—deliberately challenged the narrow interpretation of the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments, which had extended constitutional protections to former slaves but explicitly maintained gender-based restrictions. When prosecuted for this transgression, Anthony leveraged her trial as a platform for articulating a comprehensive argument for women's full political personhood. Her defense brilliantly exposed the fundamental contradiction between America's democratic ideals and its gendered exclusionary practices. Although convicted and fined (a fine she strategically refused to pay), Anthony succeeded in transforming what could have been a mere symbolic protest into a substantive constitutional challenge that resonated throughout the nation.

(4) The contemporary feminist movement owes an immeasurable debt to Anthony's organizational innovations. Her strategic emphasis on building a decentralized network of local and state suffrage societies, connected through national coordination, established an infrastructure that would be emulated by subsequent social movements. Anthony intuitively understood that sustainable activism required both grassroots mobilization and institutional continuity. Her approach balanced charismatic leadership with systematic organization-building, ensuring the movement would outlive any individual contributor. Furthermore, Anthony's recognition of media as a crucial battleground for public opinion foreshadowed modern advocacy tactics. She skillfully utilized newspapers, speaking tours, and political conventions to disseminate suffragist arguments, effectively countering the often-hostile mainstream press coverage through alternative communication channels.

(5) Anthony did not live to see the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment in 1920, which prohibited voter discrimination on the basis of sex, yet her influence permeates contemporary gender equality discourse in complex and sometimes contradictory ways. While her unwavering commitment to women's political enfranchisement undoubtedly accelerated its achievement, modern scholars have rightfully critiqued the racial and class limitations of early suffragist rhetoric. The movement Anthony helped lead occasionally subordinated the intersectional concerns of women of color and working-class women to secure support from more privileged constituencies. This critical reassessment does not diminish Anthony's remarkable contributions but rather contextualizes them within the broader, ongoing struggle for comprehensive equality. Today's intersectional feminist movements build upon Anthony's foundational work while consciously expanding beyond its limitations, embodying both continuity with and evolution from her pioneering legacy.

questions.question: Select the sentence that correctly uses inversion:

options.A: Never I have seen such a magnificent sunset.
options.B: Not only did she win the competition, but she also broke the record.
options.C: Under no circumstances we should compromise on quality.
options.D: Seldom the train arrives on time during winter months.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a correctly used prepositional phrase?

options.A: The children were excited for going to the museum.
options.B: She succeeded despite of the numerous obstacles.
options.C: In accordance with the new regulations, all visitors must register online.
options.D: The research was conducted with the view of finding a cure.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct use of a compound adjective:

options.A: The company needs well qualified personnel for this position.
options.B: We stayed at a five-stars hotel during our vacation.
options.C: The state-of-the-art facility has attracted international researchers.
options.D: They purchased a high quality equipment for the laboratory.

questions.question: Select the sentence that correctly uses the future in the past:

options.A: She said that she will attend the conference next week.
options.B: I was certain that the project would be completed by December.
options.C: They had promised they will deliver the goods on Friday.
options.D: We hoped the weather will improve for the outdoor event.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct use of a past modal verb:

options.A: You must told him about the change in plans.
options.B: She could finished the assignment earlier if she had tried harder.
options.C: They might had arrived on time if they had taken a different route.
options.D: We should have considered all options before making a decision.

questions.question: Identify the sentence that correctly uses the impersonal passive:

options.A: It is widely believed that the ancient structure predates the Roman era.
options.B: They think that the economy will recover by next year.
options.C: People say that the forest is haunted at night.
options.D: The scientists have claimed that the discovery is revolutionary.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses an emphatic structure with 'do/did'?

options.A: I do believe that honesty is the best policy.
options.B: They did finished the project before the deadline.
options.C: She does works hard to achieve her goals.
options.D: We do went to that restaurant last week.

questions.question: Select the sentence that is correctly formed as a cleft sentence:

options.A: It was in Paris where they first met each other.
options.B: What I need is a long vacation in a quiet place.
options.C: It was the director who gave the final approval for the project.
options.D: The reason why he left early because he had another appointment.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'what' or 'such' for emphasis?

options.A: What a talented musician he is!

questions.question: Select the sentence that correctly demonstrates the perfect aspect:

options.A: By next month, I will be working at this company for ten years.
options.B: I have been waiting for three hours when she finally arrived.
options.C: By the time the guests arrive, I will have been cooking for six hours.
options.D: She has completed the course since last year.

questions.question: Identify the sentence containing a nominal relative clause:

options.A: The book that I borrowed from the library is overdue.
options.B: What you said during the meeting shocked everyone.
options.C: I don't know the reason why he resigned.
options.D: The house where I grew up has been demolished.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with proper shifting of tenses in reported speech:

options.A: She said that she has already submitted the application.
options.B: He told me that he will attend the ceremony next week.
options.C: They announced that the train is delayed by two hours.
options.D: The professor explained that water boiled at 100 degrees Celsius.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses a phrasal verb with a different meaning than its literal components suggest?

options.A: The detective will look into the mysterious disappearance.
options.B: Please put down your bag on the table.
options.C: They walked up the stairs to the third floor.
options.D: She turned around to see who called her name.

questions.question: Select the sentence that correctly uses an advanced reporting verb:

options.A: She said to be careful on the icy road.
options.B: He told that the meeting was canceled.
options.C: The witness alleged that she had seen the suspect at the crime scene.
options.D: They complained they were treated unfairly.

questions.question: Identify the correctly formed mixed conditional sentence:

options.A: If I studied harder, I would have passed the exam.
options.B: If I had studied medicine, I would be a doctor now.
options.C: If I would study harder, I would pass the exam.
options.D: If I had studied harder, I would passed the exam.

questions.question: Choose the most suitable word to complete this sentence: "Despite his usually _____ demeanor, the CEO became quite animated during the discussion about the new product line."
Select the word that best fits in this sentence: "The once-prosperous industrial town had fallen into a _____ state of decay and moral corruption."
Which word best completes this sentence? "The normally confident speaker appeared _____ as she approached the podium, her hands visibly shaking as she arranged her notes."
Choose the word that best fits in this context: "His _____ remarks were delivered with such charm and fluency that few in the audience noticed how little substance they contained."
Select the most appropriate word to complete this sentence: "The politician's decision to openly _____ international trade agreements drew criticism from diplomats worldwide."
Choose the most fitting word for this sentence: "The company's _____ position enabled it to weather the economic downturn more successfully than its heavily indebted competitors."
Which word best completes this sentence? "The new employee impressed everyone with her quick-witted _____ during the otherwise tense meeting."
Select the most appropriate word for this context: "The use of typewriters in the modern office environment seemed _____ until the power outage rendered all computers unusable."
Choose the word that best fits in this sentence: "The historian decided to _____ the ancient manuscripts to find evidence supporting her controversial theory."
Which word best completes this sentence? "After the scandal, he became a _____ in the business community, shunned by former colleagues and denied entry to the social clubs he once frequented."
Select the word that best fits this context: "His _____ voice echoed through the empty crypt, sending chills down the spines of the few visitors present."
Choose the most appropriate word for this sentence: "His comment was particularly _____ to the ongoing discussion about educational reform."
Which word best completes this sentence? "The diplomat's explanation was needlessly _____, repeating the same concept using different words without adding any new information."
Select the most appropriate word for this context: "The investigation followed a _____ path through a labyrinth of corporate entities, offshore accounts, and shell companies."
Choose the word that best completes this sentence: "The young researcher appeared _____ when presenting her findings to the panel of distinguished scientists."
Select the most appropriate phrase to complete this sentence: "The committee _____ the proposal after discovering several critical flaws."
Choose the appropriate idiomatic expression: "After years of struggling as an unknown artist, her latest exhibition has really _____."

options.B: hit the nail on the head

questions.question: Select the correct collocation to complete this sentence: "The new evidence _____ serious doubts about the defendant's guilt."
Choose the most appropriate transitional phrase: "The company's profits increased by 15%; _____, employee bonuses were reduced."
Select the most appropriate formal alternative for the underlined expression: "The government needs to LOOK INTO this issue immediately."
Choose the correct hedging language to complete this formal academic sentence: "The results _____ that the treatment is effective, but further research is necessary."
Select the most precise word to complete this sentence: "The diplomat's response was deliberately _____, avoiding any clear position on the controversial issue."
Choose the most appropriate binomial phrase: "The agreement was declared null and _____ after evidence of fraud emerged."
Select the correct fixed expression: "_____ recent developments, we need to revise our strategy."
Choose the most appropriate expression to complete this formal statement: "The board wishes to _____ its appreciation for the staff's dedication during this challenging period."
According to paragraph 1, what distinguished Susan B. Anthony from many of her contemporaries?

options.A: Her focus exclusively on voting rights
options.C: Her recognition that political enfranchisement was fundamental to other reforms
options.D: Her unwillingness to face ridicule and arrest

questions.question: The passage suggests that Anthony's partnership with Elizabeth Cady Stanton was characterized by:

options.A: Complete agreement on all tactical decisions
options.B: Complementary skills that enhanced their effectiveness despite occasional conflicts
options.C: A dominant-subordinate relationship with Anthony leading
options.D: A focus exclusively on publishing rather than activism

questions.question: According to paragraph 3, how did Anthony transform her 1872 illegal voting act?

options.A: By paying a significant fine that funded the suffrage movement
options.B: By using her trial to articulate comprehensive arguments for women's citizenship
options.C: By accepting the court's ruling without protest
options.D: By encouraging all women to vote illegally in subsequent elections

questions.question: Based on paragraph 4, which organizational innovation is attributed to Anthony?

options.A: Centralized leadership with all decisions made at the national level
options.B: Reliance solely on charismatic leadership without institutional structures
options.C: A decentralized network of local and state societies with national coordination
options.D: Avoiding media engagement to prevent hostile coverage

questions.question: The word 'permeates' in paragraph 5 most closely means:
According to the passage, modern scholarly critiques of Anthony's work focus on:

options.A: Her failure to achieve voting rights in her lifetime
options.B: Her limited understanding of political strategy
options.C: The racial and class limitations in early suffragist approaches
options.D: Her conflicts with Elizabeth Cady Stanton

questions.question: The passage characterizes today's intersectional feminist movements as:

options.B: Building upon Anthony's work while expanding beyond its limitations
options.D: Unrelated to the historical suffrage movement

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Anthony's approach to activism according to the passage?

options.B: Strategically pragmatic with a focus on long-term goals
options.D: Avoiding controversial positions to maintain popularity

questions.question: The main purpose of this passage is to:

options.A: Provide a strictly chronological account of Anthony's life
options.B: Compare Anthony unfavorably with modern feminist leaders
options.C: Analyze Anthony's strategic contributions to women's rights movements and their contemporary relevance
options.D: Argue that Anthony's methods are no longer relevant to modern feminism

questions.question: What does the passage suggest about Anthony's civil disobedience in voting illegally?

options.A: It was an impulsive act with no strategic purpose
options.B: It was primarily motivated by personal recognition
options.C: It deliberately challenged constitutional interpretations of citizenship
options.D: It was condemned by other suffragists as too radical
